TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr R.A.U. Baron PERSON a lawyer practising in GPE .
a. Particular circumstances of the present case

The family of the applicant ’s mother belongs to the NORP nobility . Her family is entitled to carry the NORP noble title of Count ( PERSON ) . The family of the applicant ’s father does not belong to the NORP nobility . Following his GPE divorce , the applicant officially changed his family name to his mother ’s maiden name . It appears that the applicant has added “ PERSON as the last of his first names .

On DATE , he requested the Minister for the ORG ( Minister PERSON ) to include him in the GPE ancestry register ( filiatieregister ) , which would entitle him to carry a noble title . However , as in the GPE nobility is only transferred through the paternal line , the Minister rejected his request on DATE . The applicant ’s objection ( bezwaar ) against this decision was rejected by the Minister on DATE .
The applicant ’s appeal against this decision was dismissed by ORG ( ORG ) of GPE on DATE . The applicant filed a further appeal with ORG ( Afdeling Bestuursrechtspraak ) of ORG .

In an article published on DATE in the DATE “ ORG ” , it was reported that FAC , who is the formal President of ORG , and the Minister for the ORG pursue a policy of not intervening in the natural decrease of the number of persons belonging to the NORP nobility .

On DATE , the applicant ’s case was heard before ORG . CARDINAL of its members , PERSON , repeatedly interrupted the applicant ’s lawyer and only displayed a negative interest in the applicant ’s submissions .

On DATE , the applicant challenged ( wraking ) PERSON on grounds of bias . On DATE , the applicant further challenged all members of ORG ( PERSON ) of ORG , arguing that the entire ORG can not be regarded as impartial .
On DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s request of DATE and , as the applicant apparently sought to obtain a decision from ORG , did not deal with his request of DATE .
On DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal against ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE .

Insofar as the applicant complained that the NORP rules on transferral of noble titles is contrary to the prohibition of discrimination under the relevant provisions in a number of international instruments , ORG held that there is an objective and reasonable ground for the difference in treatment as regards transferral of noble titles which lies in the circumstance that it concerns a historical institution which derives its right of existence solely from that historical character and therefore does not lend itself for adaptation to more recent views on equal treatment . ORG further noted that this difference in treatment applies equally to both men and women .

Pursuant to the LAW on Nobility ( Wet op de Adeldom ) , and apart from the situation in which a NORP noble title is transmitted via the paternal line at birth , ennoblement can only take place by elevation ( verheffing ) or incorporation ( inlijving ) . Elevation is only possible for members of the GPE royal family . Incorporation is only possible for persons belonging to a foreign family with a recognised noble status in their country of origin and only where a request for incorporation has been made on the moment the person concerned obtains NORP nationality .

Ennoblement takes place by LAW ) . Under the relevant provisions of NORP law governing names , noble titles and predicates form a part of a noble person ’s family name . The unlawful carrying of a noble title may attract consequences under NORP criminal law .

In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ( Case no . RCARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) , ORG held that noble status is to be regarded as a historically grown institute to which , since DATE , no longer any rights and freedoms pertain .
